title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997". Congress acknowledges the rapid growth of private security officers in the United States, who work alongside public law enforcement to prevent and reduce crime. The private security industry offers entry-level opportunities for job seekers, including those affected by economic challenges. These officers protect individuals and various properties such as banks, hospitals, airports, and schools, complementing the services provided by sworn law enforcement officers. The growth of private security officers in the United States has accelerated rapidly, with the public having more contact with them than with sworn law enforcement officers. This trend has increased as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased, leading to challenges in discerning between the two. The demand for more public sector law enforcement officers to combat serious crimes is also highlighted. The American public demands well-trained private security personnel as an adjunct, not a replacement for sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers should be thoroughly screened, especially since many carry weapons. SEC. 3. BACKGROUND CHECKS. Employers of private security officers can request an association designated by the Attorney General to submit fingerprints for background checks. The Attorney General will search criminal records and provide results within 30 days. The use of advanced technology is encouraged for compiling criminal history information. An association designated by the Attorney General must promptly submit employee fingerprints for identification and processing. They are also required to transfer identification and criminal history records to employers and relevant licensing authorities within one business day. The Attorney General has the authority to establish regulations for the security, accuracy, and dissemination of information, as well as impose necessary fees for cost recovery. The Attorney General requires an association to submit employee fingerprints promptly for identification and processing, transfer records to employers and licensing authorities within one business day, and establish regulations for information security. The Attorney General will report to Congress on the number of inquiries made by employers under this section after 2 years. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS.

Subsection (d) of section 534 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include an association of employers of private security officers designated by the Attorney General for conducting background checks.

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY.

Anyone who misuses information obtained under section 3 for purposes other than assessing an individual's suitability for private security officer employment may face a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to two years.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY.

Employers relying on criminal history information provided by the Attorney General for employment decisions are protected from liability in any damages action.

SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Attorney General," "employee," "employer," "fingerprint," and "private security officer." It includes individuals who provide security services as independent contractors or employees, whether armed or unarmed. The Act defines key terms and includes individuals providing security services as independent contractors or employees, excluding sworn police officers, licensed professionals, internal audit or credit employees, military personnel, and electronic security system company technicians or monitors. The Act defines security services as the performance of various tasks including observation, reporting, deterrence of theft, protection of individuals and property, control of access, and maintenance of order and safety. The Act defines security services as tasks such as observation, reporting, theft deterrence, protection of individuals and property, access control, maintenance of order and safety, and provision of canine services for protection or detection of unlawful substances. The term "State" includes several states and territories. SEC. 8. USER FEES. The Attorney General may collect a user fee for a request for an individual's criminal history information. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act will be effective on July 1, 1999.
